name: Electron microscopy
definition: visual and photographic microscopy in which electron beams with wavelengths thousands of times shorter than visible light are used in place of light, thereby allowing much greater magnification.

name: Light microscopy
definition: using a beam of visible light and optical magnification to image a specimen.

name: Confocal scanning microscopy
definition: indirect imaging technique which uses a sharply focused light source (typically a laser) to excite fluors or otherwise visualize the specimen one point at a time; 2 or 3 dimensional likenesses are then reconstructed by computer; relatively noninvasive, applicable to thick sections and living tissue.

name: Ultraviolet microscopy
definition: microscopy in which the image is formed by ultraviolet radiation.

name: High voltage electron microscopy
definition: type of transmission EM employing an electron beam powerful enough to penetrate thick (up to 2 u) sections which, when precisely tilted through a range of angles, produces a series of images that can be computer processed into a 3-dimensional likeness of the specimen.

name: Atomic force microscopy
definition: indirect, molecular-resolution imaging technique in which 3- dimensional tracings of a mobile probe across the specimen's surface are processed by computer into a topological image; in contrast to STM the probe is driven only by the mechanical resistance (topology and viscoelasticity) of the surface.

name: Scanning transmission electron microscopy
definition: form of electron microscopy based on scanning with an extremely narrow beam that is transmitted through the sample; the detection apparatus produces an image whose brightness depends on the atomic number of the sample, and therefore reveals chemical composition as well as gross molecular shape.

name: Transmission electron microscopy
definition: original electron microscopic technique; the photographic imaging of a sample created by a beam of electrons passing through a thin section; resolution ranges from macromolecular to cellular.

name: Immunoelectron microscopy
definition: microscopy in which the samples are first stained immunocytochemically and then examined using an electron microscope.

name: Intravital microscopy
definition: observation of a system in a living organism by microscopy.

name: Scanning electron microscopy
definition: microscopy in which the object is examined directly by an electron beam scanning the specimen point by point, giving the surface image a three dimensional quality.

name: Cryoelectron microscopy
definition: three-dimensional image reconstruction technique whereby an aqueous suspension of a sample is applied in an extremely thin film to a grid, frozen in liquid nitrogen, maintained in this state by means of a special mount, and then observed in the electron microscope.

name: Interference microscopy
definition: microscopy utilizing a direct beam of light which splits and recombines as it passes through the specimen, forming a pattern that corresponds to variations in the specimen's thickness and refraction; used to examine transparent objects such as living cells.

name: Video microscopy
definition: video recording of images formed by a microscope.

name: Infrared microscopy
definition: microscopy in which the image is formed by infrared radiation.

name: Phase contrast microscopy
definition: form of interference microscopy in which variations of the refracting index in the object are converted into variations of intensity in the image.

name: Scanning tunneling microscopy
definition: indirect, molecular-resolution imaging technique based on the surface tracings of a mobile probe; in contrast to AFM the probe is driven by ionic tunneling and the image therefore depends on the conductance properties of the specimen.

name: Fluorescence microscopy
definition: microscope that irradiates fluorescent materials or specimens with ultraviolet, violet, and occasionally blue light, causing the materials to fluoresce.
